factoid: An unnamed man kept repeating "Natalie, just a word, only one!"
An unnamed man was evidently not knowing what to say.
An unnamed man repeated it until Hélène came up to them.
Hélène returned with Natásha to the drawing room.
The Rostóvs went away without staying for supper.
After reaching home, Natásha did not sleep all night.
Natásha was tormented by the insoluble question whether she loved Anatole or Prince Andrew.
Natásha loved Prince Andrew.
Natásha remembered distinctly how deeply she loved Prince Andrew.
Natásha loved Anatole.
There was no doubt that Natásha loved Anatole.
Natásha wondered how all this could have happened.
If Natásha could return Prince Andrew's smile when saying goodbye, it would mean she loved him from the first.
Natásha believed Prince Andrew is kind, noble, and splendid.
Natásha could not help loving Prince Andrew.
Natásha wondered what she should do if she loves Prince Andrew and Anatole too.
Natásha was unable to find an answer to these terrible questions.
Morning came with cares and bustle.
Everyone got up and began to move about and talk.
Dressmakers came again.
Márya Dmítrievna appeared.
They were called to breakfast.
Natásha kept looking uneasily at everybody with wide‑open eyes.
Natásha wished to intercept every glance directed toward her.
Natásha tried to appear the same as usual.
After breakfast, Márya Dmítrievna sat down in her armchair.
Márya Dmítrievna called Natásha and the count to her.
Márya Dmítrievna said she had thought the whole matter over and this is her advice.
Yesterday, Márya Dmítrievna went to see Prince Bolkónski.
Márya Dmítrievna had a talk with Prince Bolkónski.
Prince Bolkónski took it into his head to begin shouting.
Márya Dmítrievna is not one to be shouted down.
Márya Dmítrievna said what she had to say.
The count asked what happened with Prince Bolkónski.
Márya Dmítrievna said Prince Bolkónski is crazy.
Prince Bolkónski did not want to listen.
Márya Dmítrievna said that talking has no use.
Márya Dmítrievna said they have worn the poor girl out.
Márya Dmítrievna advised Natásha to finish her business and go back home to Otrádnoe.
Márya Dmítrievna advised Natásha to wait there.
Natásha exclaimed "Oh, no!"
Márya Dmítrievna said Natásha should go back.
Márya Dmítrievna said Natásha should wait there.
If Natásha's betrothed comes here now, there will be no avoiding a quarrel.
If Natásha is alone with Prince Bolkónski, he will talk things over and then come on to Natásha.
Count Rostóv approved of this suggestion.
Count Rostóv appreciated its reasonableness.
If Prince Bolkónski came round, it would be better to visit him in Moscow or at Bald Hills later on.
If Prince Bolkónski did not come round, the wedding, against his wishes, could only be arranged at Otrádnoe.
The old count said that is perfectly true.
The old count apologized for going to see him and taking her.
Márya Dmítrievna said "No, why be sorry?"
Márya Dmítrievna said that being here, you had to pay your respects.
Márya Dmítrievna said that if Prince Bolkónski won't, that's his affair.
The trousseau is ready.
There is nothing to wait for.
What is not ready will be sent after.
Márya Dmítrievna said she does not have to let you go.
Márya Dmítrievna said it is the best way.
Márya Dmítrievna told Natásha to go with God's blessing.
Márya Dmítrievna found what she was looking for in the reticule.
Márya Dmítrievna handed the letter from Princess Mary to Natásha.
The letter was from Princess Mary.
Princess Mary has written to Natásha.
Princess Mary torments herself.
Princess Mary is afraid Natásha might think that she does not like Natásha.
Natásha said that Princess Mary doesn't like her.
Márya Dmítrievna told Natásha not to talk nonsense.
Natásha replied that she will not believe anyone and knows that Princess Mary doesn't like her.
Natásha's face expressed a cold and angry resolution.
Márya Dmítrievna looked at Natásha more intently.
Márya Dmítrievna frowned.
Márya Dmítrievna told Natásha not to answer like that.
Márya Dmítrievna said what she says is true.
Márya Dmítrievna told Natásha to write an answer.
Natásha did not reply.
Natásha went to her own room to read Princess Mary's letter.
Princess Mary wrote that she was in despair at the misunderstanding that had occurred between them.
Whatever Princess Mary's father's feelings might be, Princess Mary begged Natásha to believe that she could not help loving Natásha as the one chosen by her brother.
Princess Mary was ready to sacrifice everything for her brother's happiness.
